channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Swiss Franc Rises on U.S.-Switzerland Trade Deal Hopes
item.description: The Swiss franc rose to a near one-week high against the euro on hopes for a trade deal between the U.S. and Switzerland.

item.title: U.K. Unemployment Climbs as Bank of England Mulls December Rate Cut
item.description: The unemployment rate rose in the third quarter, making it more likely the Bank of England will cut borrowing costs in December.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Capital Account—How Chile is fending off the extremes of Right and Left wing Populism
item.description: The coming presidential election pits a communist against a conservative Catholic. The country’s centrist institutions will likely prevail.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: The Grim Reality Is That the RBA Is Done Cutting Rates
item.description: The grim realization that is now settling over Australian money markets and the many millions of home buyers battling enormous mortgage debts, is that the Reserve Bank of Australia is almost assuredly done lowering interest rates
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Europe’s Economic Recovery Hopes Hang on Scarred Consumers
item.description: While the economy appears to have survived a jump in U.S. tariffs, households will have to put half a decade of trauma behind them if the region is to significantly recover.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Paper wealth is powering this economy. And it can disappear just as quickly as it was created.
item.description: Investors’ rosy feelings about their stock market gains are powering spending—but it’s a different story for everyone else.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Wolfe

item.title: BOJ Summary of Opinions Show Next Rate-Hike Nearing
item.description: The Bank of Japan’s policy board has signaled that the next interest-rate increase may be coming soon, according to its latest summary of opinions, with members keeping a particular eye on domestic wage trends.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: RBA Fears Capacity Constraints Could Limit Scope for Rate Cuts
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia has warned that the rate cut path could be narrow given elevated levels of capacity utilization in the economy and an outlook that includes uncomfortably high inflation well into next year.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Consumers’ moods dropped further in November, according to a monthly survey from the University of Michigan
item.description: The University of Michigan survey reading is slightly above levels that sentiment sank to amid the historic inflation that hit in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Sam Goldfarb

item.title: Canada Unemployment Rate Falls to 6.9% in October
item.description: Canada saw another month of unexpectedly strong hiring in October, pulling the jobless rate down for the first time in four months and offering an early hint the struggling economy is steadying.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: German Exports Climbed in September on U.S. Trade Deal
item.description: Exports were helped by a bump in trade with the U.S. after the EU agreed to a deal, however, goods sent across the Atlantic were still down 14% compared with the same point of last year.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Chinese exports contracted in October from a year earlier, dragged by a high base of comparison and cooling overseas demand after months of front-loading
item.description: Exports contracted in October from a year earlier, dragged by a high base of comparison and cooling overseas demand after months of front-loading.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miao

item.title: Fed’s Williams Expects Central Bank to Return to Asset Purchases Soon
item.description: New York Fed President John Williams says recent volatility in repo markets shows that a modest level of Fed bond purchases will soon be needed to keep overnight lending markets supplied at appropriate levels.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Norway’s Central Bank Confirms It Is in No Rush to Lower Borrowing Costs Further
item.description: Norway’s central bank held its key policy rate at 4% on Thursday and reiterated plans to ease monetary policy slowly in the coming years.
item.dc:creator: Dominic Chopping

item.title: The Bank of Mexico extended its monetary easing cycle with an 11th consecutive cut in its benchmark interest-rate, and kept the door open to more reductions in the future
item.description: The board of governors lowered the benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 7.25% and kept the door open to future reductions.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Harrup

item.title: Employers said they cut more than a million jobs so far this year, a sharp rise in job losses compared with the same period last year, according to a new report
item.description: The report from private consulting firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas shows a sharp rise in job losses in the first 10 months of the year.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Eurozone Retail Sales Edge Lower Despite Improving Sentiment
item.description: Retail sales unexpectedly inched lower in September, contrasting with some of the rosier sentiment among consumers in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Heard on the Street: New homes are sitting unsold, despite the discounted mortgages that builders are offering
item.description: New homes are sitting unsold, despite builders using sweeteners to shift inventory.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: German Industrial Production Rebounds Weakly Amid Tentative Hopes Over Outlook
item.description: Industrial production in Europe’s largest economy rose moderately, with expectations that the sector’s outlook could improve ahead of large-scale government investment.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: A planned $2.5 billion potash mine in the Amazon is billed as key to Brazil’s expanding agricultural exports and to the economic security of the indigenous population
item.description: A planned $2.5 billion potash mine in the rainforest is billed as key to Brazil’s expanding agricultural exports and to the economic security of the indigenous population.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Pearson

item.title: The U.S. added 42,000 private-sector jobs in October, payroll-processing giant ADP, with trade, education and healthcare sectors driving gains
item.description: The modest job growth in ADP’s report offers some reassurance that the soft labor market isn’t worsening.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Early worries about the economic impact of President Trump’s sweeping tariffs now seem overblown
item.description: Inflation is lower than expected after President Trump’s steep levies.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Corporate America has ended its firing freeze, as major companies have announced tens of thousands of layoffs in recent weeks
item.description: The practice of ‘labor hoarding’—holding on to employees for fear of not being able to get them back later—has reached its end.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: The party goes on in New York City, if you have the cash
item.description: The city has thousands of millionaires and they keep spending, powering a burgeoning local economy that caters to the well-to-do.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: Big power bills are overlapping with rising food prices and inflation, frustrating many Americans
item.description: Data centers are contributing to higher prices as fat energy bills electrify local politics.
item.dc:creator: Jared Mitovich

item.title: Foreign Investment on Track for Third Year of Decline, UN Figures Show
item.description: Foreign direct investment fell 3% in the first six months of the year due to trade uncertainty, geopolitical tension and high interest rates, said the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Slows, Leaving ECB in Its Good Place
item.description: The annual rate of inflation in the eurozone slowed in October to just above the European Central Bank’s target.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: More home-purchase agreements are being scrapped around the country, reflecting a growing standoff between buyers and sellers in a largely stalled housing market
item.description: Buyers worried about job prospects are getting cold feet, or realizing that costs will be higher than expected.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: From Amazon to Target, the country’s largest employers are retrenching, laying off tens of thousands of office workers
item.description: Layoffs at companies ranging from Amazon to Target are sending young and experienced workers alike into an unwelcoming market.
item.dc:creator: Allison Pohle

item.title: Watering down dish soap. Trading down to grocery discounters. Buying half a cow. Americans struggling with higher costs are going to great lengths to stretch spending on food and household staples
item.description: From buying half a cow to watering down dish soap, people are increasingly experimenting with frugality—and it is affecting sales at consumer companies.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Khan

item.title: U.S. And European Business Activity Pick Up in Continued Show Of Resilience
item.description: A rise in activity in the U.S., Europe and Asia indicates that the global economy remains resilient in the face of higher tariffs and greater uncertainty about relations between powerful countries.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Home sales rose in September to a seven-month high after buyers seized on declining mortgage rates
item.description: ​Sales r​eached a seven-month high, offering some hope that the housing market could be improving.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: PulteGroup Profit Falls as Housing Market Remains Stalled
item.description: PulteGroup recorded a lower third-quarter profit as affordability concerns continued to put off home buyers.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas G. Miller

item.title: Canada Existing-Home Sales Fall in September
item.description: Existing-home sales in Canada declined in September from the previous month, and prices fell to their lowest level in over four years.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: A reduction in the tariffs faced by Indian businesses exporting to the U.S. would likely boost growth this year, Reserve Bank of India Gov. Sanjay Malhotra said
item.description: Sanjay Malhotra said talks are under way to lower tariffs, and success would help lift the economy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: IMF Chief Sees Global Growth Slowing ‘Only Slightly’ in Face of Higher Tariffs
item.description: The global economy is holding up better than expected in the face of higher tariffs and greater uncertainty about relations between powerful countries and the implications of technological change, the head of the International Monetary Fund said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
